Question: A researcher wants to determine whether a new study method improves test scores.
She randomly assigns 100 high school students to two groups: 50 students use the new study method (treatment group), while 50 students use their regular study methods (control group).
After two weeks, all students take the same test, and the treatment group scores 8 points higher on average than the control group.
However, when analyzing the data further, the researcher discovers that the treatment group spent an average of 3 more hours studying than the control group during the two-week period.

What is the primary flaw in this experimental design, and how could the researcher modify the design to better determine whether the new study method itself (rather than study time) causes improved test scores? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Alright, so I'm trying to figure out the primary flaw in this researcher's experimental design.
Let's break down the problem step by step.
First, the setup: There are 100 high school students split into two groups of 50.
One group uses a new study method, and the other continues with their regular methods.
After two weeks, they all take the same test.
The treatment group scores 8 points higher on average.
But then the researcher notices that the treatment group actually spent an average of 3 more hours studying than the control group during the two weeks.
Hmm, so the treatment group not only used a new method but also studied more.
That makes me think about variables here.
The study method and the study time are both changing, but the test score is the outcome.

So, is the higher score due to the new study method or just the extra study time?

I remember something about confounding variables in experiments.
A confounding variable is one that isn't controlled for and affects the results, making it hard to determine the true cause and effect.
In this case, study time is a confounding variable because both groups might have different study times, and that could influence test scores.
Wait, but the problem says the treatment group spent more time studying.
So, if they studied more, it's possible that their higher scores are just because they studied longer, not necessarily because of the new method.
The researcher might be attributing the higher score to the new method when it could be the extra study time.
So the primary flaw is that the treatment group's additional study time isn't controlled.
The control group didn't use the new method, but they also didn't study as much.
This means the higher scores could be due to either the new method or the extra study time, making it unclear which is the actual cause.
To fix this, the researcher should probably keep the study time the same for both groups.
Maybe set a specific study time for both groups, like 3 hours a week, so that any differences in study time are eliminated.
Then, if the treatment group still scores higher, it would be because of the new method, not because they studied more.
Another way could be to randomize the study time as well.
But I think keeping study time constant is more straightforward.
That way, the only difference is the study method, and the effect on test scores can be more accurately measured.
So, in summary, the main issue is the confounding variable of study time.
By controlling for study time, the researcher can better isolate the effect of the new study method.

</think>

The primary flaw in the experimental design is that the treatment group spent more time studying than the control group, introducing a confounding variable.
To isolate the effect of the new study method, the researcher should ensure that both groups study for the same amount of time.
This way, any differences in test scores can be attributed solely to the study method used.
